{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3619104,"name":"Martin Pirringer","username":"mpirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-10T18:21:51.719Z","cooked":"

Hi,

We are building a Comunity bot that will run on 12 V etc like a FRC bot. Unfortunately cost is an issue. So the idea is to use old parts. Now buying a new roborio etc would be a budget buster. So the IDEA is to use an XRP board and use some sparkfun level converters to convert the 3.3V PWM signals to 5V and drive some old Victor 884,883,SP and Jaguar controllers to drive old on hand CIM motors. We could use an Arduino to do that but the XRP advantage is that there is a wpilib and so the programming is familiar and everyone could use to practices stuff on it too. So in effect we would replace the ROBOrio with an XRP. The old controllers are servo controllers so there should be the possibility to pull the pwm of motor 1-4 and servo 1-4 off the header and control up to 8 motors. Our design right now uses 7 so no need to use some of the unused pins. There are other projects waiting for something like this if it works

So question: Anyone do this already and is willing to share? Any ideas? or should we go with an arduino or ESP32 solution and write stuff “from scratch” - well using the arduino servo library? Ideally we (the kids and me) could use something as close as possible to FRC without going into spending 500 bucks for a roborio per creation the XRP boards are less than 10% of that…

OF course if successful - willing to share

My main caution regarding doing something like this is on the safety side. The controller, the protocol, and how the sim version of the DS works are all not designed to be safety critical. It doesn’t matter with a XRP sized robot, but it matters a lot when you’re talking about controlling a FRC scale power and weight robot.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-05-10T21:10:41.602Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":47.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501527,"topic_slug":"use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24690,"username":"mpirringer","name":"Martin Pirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8002,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"177 & 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers/501527/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3622990,"name":"Martin Pirringer","username":"mpirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-13T15:13:22.611Z","cooked":"

Could you elaborate on that safety aspect in particular? I get it that the FRC bot can be shut down by the field on the field but outside the field like this robot(s) and contraptions would be used I don’t see the added safety beyond what you program in no matter what HW (Roborio, Arduino, ESP32, Pi etc) you use. I have been doing this for 15 years now and maybe I have been doing something wrong for 15 years but off the field there is nothing beyond your program that keeps the robot and its environment safe. An infinite loop and it takes off until it hits something or someone. A bad command and it can theoretically self destruct by keeping climbing until it crushes some ill placed electronics and a poorly aimed shooter can hit someone in the head or take out a window etc etc etc. So for a semi autonomous or even 100% rc robot even with roborio you got to program stuff in to not hit stuff or self destruct and the robot is going to be as safe and effective as the program. I have done arduino stuff with BTS7960 with Current control to limit the CIM motor or 550 style ones power. We had with roborio programs to take off in auto in direction of a wall and stop when the current hit 8 amps (using talon srx) and not forget keeping the robot from self destructing using limit switches and encoders and pots etc. Seems to me when you come down to it a Roborio is an arduino style board with a little bit more umpf and probably the IO capability of a Mega with a storage device. Now you also can do CAN with an arduino esp32 or Pi type board. So comes down to the software. The advantage of the XRP board is it got WPI library for it so its a smaller learning curve for everyone involved and the smaller size of the XRP bot makes programming mistakes less damaging so there is that but if you scale to a “full sized” 150ish lb (including batt and bumper) FRC bot I don’t see the extra safety from using a roborio. We (me and a good number of kids on multiple teams) over 15 years now have broken quite a few things on and off the bot in testing even with the “safe” roborio. Hence we have protocols like the drive train gets tested on blocks first. Each motion gets tested in each direction to see if it breaks anything and their are climbing and aiming procedures to make sure no people and windows etc get harmed and “Crowd control” during testing and of course the apropriate PPE. Things like “watchdog” and emergency shutoff etc etc can also be installed on non roborio powered machines. And yes it all comes down to the robot. I did my first animatronic robot for trade show purposes in 79 (did not have a roborio lol) with TMS9900 family microprocessors and self designed etched and drilled custom “microcontroller” boards using self rolled H-Bridges to drive motors bigger than a CIM. With a radio shack radio and EPROMs for storage and robots weighing up to 300lb and yes even back then it came down to the software to not self destruct and/or do damage and the good old handy remote shut off or 2 and some ppl on the controls/computer screen who were safety minded, paid attention during build and test and deployment as no one wanted to deal with any potentially job ending/business ending insurance claims… not to speak of injuries.

So what am I missing. Am I wrong to consider the roborio and overpriced piece of hardware that would be much less if the target audience would not be the educational system? My main team 9713 is a community team that is struggling and the next season is always a big question mark for many reasons from recruitment for which you seem to need a good summer program to the never ending pressure on the business end mostly $$$ but also location. So using the xrp for some stuff could be a $$$ saver. And yes I can hear some voices already “if you don’t have the proper funding and infrastructure - don’t do robotics” but then we don’t live in beverly hills here. And for me what I get out of it is the number of kids (including my daughter) that went to good colleges with lots of scholarships because of it. Kids who initially did not even want to dream to go to college “We are poor maybe Community College for 2 years if I am lucky…” etc graduated from schools like Cornell, Princeton, Penn, Brown, RPI, Stevens, Rutgers just to name a few that are 4 year schools made by some who were on the free lunch program in HS etc etc etc.

Looks like I am getting a roborio for now at a good price and see what I can cook up. The most likely first use is for the ball drive which I am getting close at so stay tuned. I posted on it before, made some iterations and am about ready to put it on a frame and put some electronics with it but that probably will be a different thread.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-05-13T15:13:22.611Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":91,"readers_count":90,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501527,"topic_slug":"use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers","display_username":"Martin Pirringer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor "},"post_url":"/t/use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers/501527/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3623056,"name":"Adam Fleming","username":"AdamF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamf/{size}/234717_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-13T16:13:56.512Z","cooked":"

I’ve not played around with the XRP, but my best guess is that the XRP controller/firmware might not have the “checks” in place that the roborio has. So on the rio if an error occurs (not related to the robot code) it would catch it and shut off, where as the XRP might not have that error checking. Same with the simulated driver station; it might not disable in the same way that a roborio would.

Seeing as you are now getting a roborio this isn’t a concern for the time being, but if someone else is looking into it, my suggestion would be to only run it in a closed area with a homemade field perimeter that can take a hit. And may add an extra sb50 with a wire loop to use as a kill switch that can be yanked out.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-05-13T16:13:56.512Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":55,"readers_count":54,"score":26.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":501527,"topic_slug":"use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers","display_username":"Adam Fleming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24690,"username":"mpirringer","name":"Martin Pirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41952,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum"},"post_url":"/t/use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers/501527/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3623082,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-13T16:58:45.455Z","cooked":"
mpirringer:

Could you elaborate on that safety aspect in particular?

On the XRP controller side:

  • There is a watchdog for DS packets, but from reading the code it looks like it’s set to 500 ms. This is extremely unsafe for a FRC sized robot. Updating the firmware and lowering this value to something like 100 ms would make it a lot safer. I’m not sure if it immediately will re-enable on the next packet but it might?
  • I don’t know if anyone has tested how the PWM outputs behave in power-up or undervoltage conditions. The RoboRIO has undervoltage detection (brownout) that ensures PWMs are commanded to idle and then disabled before the controller’s software is shut off. Similarly for the power-up case, making sure there are no stray pulses that could be interpreted as motor commands is something that has been extensively tested on the Rio but not on the XRP.

On the desktop software side:

  • The commanding is done as part of the robot program running in simulation mode. If the robot program crashes, it doesn’t send a disable signal, it just stops sending control packets, so it relies on the watchdog timeout on the robot side to stop the motors. The internal sim implementation is also rather convoluted (it was built on top of the Romi websockets interface code) and has never been tested for latency or fault mode characteristics.
  • It appears (although I’d need to investigate more) that the current sim implementation also only sends control packets after each robot periodic loop. So if the robot code hangs or is very slow, the packet is also delayed, and thus it’s reliant on the robot watchdog time to stop motors here as well. Eg disabling the robot in the DS interface has no effect if the robot code is hung.
  • The sim GUI version of the DS has no global keystroke monitoring for EStop or disable; this can be mitigated by using the real DS instead of the sim one, but notably the control packets still come from the robot program in this case (so the previous bullet still applies).
","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-05-13T17:04:46.360Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":29.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501527,"topic_slug":"use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/use-xrp-to-control-frc-pmw-controllers/501527/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3623134,"name":"Martin Pirringer","username":"mpirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-13T17:54:19.695Z","cooked":"

Thanks this helps a bit As I still intend to use the XRP for some applications - probably most more or less stationary ot tethered ones.

A faster watchdog would be helpfull and the processor should be able to handle it. As if you use the XRP in a 12V system and the XRP is 3.3 V you got to use something like the 8 channel sparkfun 3.3v to 5V booster (based on some mosfets. Meaning you need a stable 5V supply (which is cheap and easy Off the shelf anyway) so that also gives you a reference voltage - so if you filter the 12 V to get out the motor noise you can measure it cheaply something you can do with some descrete components like resistors and caps and op amp and using the stable 5 v as a reference which will still be 5 V even if the input V is only lets say 7 V you can set a Voltage to trip a relay solid state or otherwise - whatever you got laying around to shut down the robot due to Voltage conditions I already did that in the late 70s and early 80s and since then. And yes gettting it for “free” in a roborio or similar is great.

Your knowledge and input regarding WPI is greatly apreciated. This is for multiple reasons for both me personal (I am retired) to create things that hopefully teach/benefit FRC and in particular promote 3DP for FRC and for “my teams” and “my kids” to learn and do some cool robotics stuff with our lean $$ pockets.

So your input is greatly apreciated. And for mobile bots a separate remote wireless shutoff has always been a part of “my creations” or the ones I supervised. Sometimes you just got to hit the stop button.
